customer_name: Wilson Horse and Mule Sale Inc

citations.narrative:
The enclosures in the auction barn used to house the ratites were not designed and constructed to be structurally sound
for the species of bird housed in them. The enclosures did not securely contain the birds.
*One ostrich was observed putting its head and neck through the wooden slats at the back of its enclosure. The enclosure
on the other side of these slats housed bovine species.
*The metal slats at the front of the ratite enclosures were spaced far enough apart that the birds could extend their head
and beak through the slats. The aisle right outside these enclosures was being used to move alpaca and llamas on Friday
such that the ratites and camelids could have access to each other.
*A rhea was housed in an enclosure adjacent to one housing a camel. The gap below the wall was over six inches in
height. A rhea was sitting next to this gap with a portion of its chest feathers extending into the enclosure housing the
camel.
Housing facilities for birds that are not structurally sound do not protect the birds from injury. Housing facilities that do not
restrict other animals from entering/having access to the birds may negatively affect the welfare of the birds and/or lead to
injury of the animals.
Housing facilities for birds must be designed and constructed so that they are structurally sound for the species of bird
housed in them. They must be kept in good repair, protect the birds from injury, and restrict other animals from entering.
Correct by May 1, 2024.

Handling of animals was not done as expeditiously and carefully as possible.
*One young water buffalo in training to allow riders on its back was tied to the wall of a stall while wearing a saddle on its
back in such a manner that it could not get up from its mostly lying down position. No person was anywhere in the area
monitoring the animal. When first inspected it was mostly lying down with its neck hyperextended and it could not get up
on its own. The white portion of the water buffalo's left eye was visible. Once the auction staff was notified and released
the saddle and untied the rope the water buffalo was able to get up on its own and move around. Tethering of the water
buffalo leads to unnecessary discomfort and behavioral stress and has the potential to cause trauma and/or physical
harm.
*To get from one auction barn to another or to the outside parking area people can use an aisleway/walkway through a
barn area used to house and sell poultry type birds. On Thursday as the inspectors were walking down this walkway, two
male peacocks were identified in their enclosures with their tail feathers extending into the walkway where people walking
by could run into them. At least one of the tailfeathers appeared broken/damaged. On Friday, another male peacock was
seen with its tailfeathers projecting into the walkway at ground level and partially covered by shavings. One person almost
stepped on the tailfeathers. These birds were not able to move out of the way of people in the walkway due to the
construction and placement of the enclosures and there was no sufficient barrier or distance between the birds and the
people. The birds may be injured if stepped on or knocked into by the public.
Handling of all animals shall be done as expeditiously and carefully as possible in a manner that does not cause trauma,
overheating, excessive cooling, behavioral stress, physical harm, or unnecessary discomfort.

Despite several major improvements including the addition of car port like roof structures over some of the outdoor
enclosures and a new gutter system on the barn, several wet enclosures were still noted on the auction grounds on
Friday.
*Four of the enclosures under the carport structure and closest to the barn have drainage issues along with a few other
enclosures along one of the aisles. The ground in these enclosures was wet and muddy throughout the entire enclosure
with no dry area for the animals to use to get out of the wet mud. One enclosure contained standing water at one end
along with the mud throughout the enclosure. Species seen housed in these wet muddy enclosures included bison, water
buffalo, zebu and cattle. The animals housed in these enclosures were standing in hoof deep mud. Their legs and
portions of their bodies were covered with mud. A sucking sound could be heard when the animals pulled their feet out of
the mud. The facility added some straw to one of the bison enclosures after it was inspected to create a dry area.
*Four enclosures housing pigs were wet and muddy. Two of the enclosures had standing water in the enclosures.
Drainage issues can lead to multiple problems including contamination of feed/hay fed on the ground, contaminated
haircoats/skin of the animals, discomfort to the animals, thermoregulatory issues, odors, fly/pest issues and unstable
slippery footing for the animals. A suitable method shall be provided to rapidly eliminate excess water.
This inspection was conducted on March 7 and 8th with a facility consultant. The exit interview was conducted on March
8th with the facility consultant and the licensee.
Additional Inspectors:
Brittany Kessler, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
3.150(a) 
   
Facilities, general. 
The enclosures in the auction barn used to house the ratites were not designed and constructed to be structurally sound 
for the species of bird housed in them. The enclosures did not securely contain the birds.  
*One ostrich was observed putting its head and neck through the wooden slats at the back of its enclosure. The enclosure 
on the other side of these slats housed bovine species.  
*The metal slats at the front of the ratite enclosures were spaced far enough apart that the birds could extend their head 
and beak through the slats. The aisle right outside these enclosures was being used to move alpaca and llamas on Friday 
such that the ratites and camelids could have access to each other.  
*A rhea was housed in an enclosure adjacent to one housing a camel. The gap below the wall was over six inches in 
height. A rhea was sitting next to this gap with a portion of its chest feathers extending into the enclosure housing the 
camel.  
Housing facilities for birds that are not structurally sound do not protect the birds from injury. Housing facilities that do not 
restrict other animals from entering/having access to the birds may negatively affect the welfare of the birds and/or lead to 
injury of the animals.  
Housing facilities for birds must be designed and constructed so that they are structurally sound for the species of bird 
housed in them. They must be kept in good repair, protect the birds from injury, and restrict other animals from entering. 
Correct by May 1, 2024. 
2.131(b)(1)  Repeat
   
Handling of animals. 
Handling of animals was not done as expeditiously and carefully as possible.  
*One young water buffalo in training to allow riders on its back was tied to the wall of a stall while wearing a saddle on its 
back in such a manner that it could not get up from its mostly lying down position. No person was anywhere in the area

the saddle and untied the rope the water buffalo was able to get up on its own and move around. Tethering of the water 
buffalo leads to unnecessary discomfort and behavioral stress and has the potential to cause trauma and/or physical 
harm.  
*To get from one auction barn to another or to the outside parking area people can use an aisleway/walkway through a

construction and placement of the enclosures and there was no sufficient barrier or distance between the birds and the

Handling of all animals shall be done as expeditiously and carefully as possible in a manner that does not cause trauma, 
overheating, excessive cooling, behavioral stress, physical harm, or unnecessary discomfort. 
3.127(c)  Repeat
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
Despite several major improvements including the addition of car port like roof structures over some of the outdoor 
enclosures and a new gutter system on the barn, several wet enclosures were still noted on the auction grounds on 
Friday.  
*Four of the enclosures under the carport structure and closest to the barn have drainage issues along with a few other 
enclosures along one of the aisles. The ground in these enclosures was wet and muddy throughout the entire enclosure

the mud. The facility added some straw to one of the bison enclosures after it was inspected to create a dry area.  
*Four enclosures housing pigs were wet and muddy. Two of the enclosures had standing water in the enclosures.  
Drainage issues can lead to multiple problems including contamination of feed/hay fed on the ground, contaminated

slippery footing for the animals. A suitable method shall be provided to rapidly eliminate excess water. 
 
This inspection was conducted on March 7 and 8th with a facility consultant. The exit interview was conducted on March 
8th with the facility consultant and the licensee. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
Brittany Kessler, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
